# Flood-control scandal keeps Philippine Q4 growth under water

##### By [Ben Arnold de Vera](https://mb.com.ph/author/ben-arnold-de-vera)

Published Dec 30, 2025 06:00 pm

![Copy Link](https://mb.com.ph/manilabulletin/uploads/global_files/share-arrow.svg)[![X](https://mb.com.ph/manilabulletin/uploads/global_files/share-x.svg)](https://x.com/intent/tweet?url=https://mb.com.ph/2025/12/30/flood-control-scandal-keeps-philippine-q4-growth-under-water)[![Facebook](https://mb.com.ph/manilabulletin/uploads/global_files/share-facebook.svg)](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://mb.com.ph/2025/12/30/flood-control-scandal-keeps-philippine-q4-growth-under-water)[![Whatsapp](https://mb.com.ph/manilabulletin/uploads/global_files/share-whatsapp.svg)](viber://forward?text=https://mb.com.ph/2025/12/30/flood-control-scandal-keeps-philippine-q4-growth-under-water)

![President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. leads the inspection of a riverwall in Barangay Piel, Baliuag, Bulacan which was tagged as a 'ghost project.' (Mark Balmores)](https://mb.com.ph/manilabulletin/uploads/global_files/no-image.jpg)

President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. leads the inspection of a riverwall in Barangay Piel, Baliuag, Bulacan which was tagged as a 'ghost project.' (Mark Balmores)

Philippine economic growth in the fourth quarter is set to once again disappoint, as spillovers from dampened public and private consumption in the aftermath of the flood-control infrastructure corruption scandal linger, according to think tank Capital Economics.
